Fields.DialogueText: All right, crew! We have two Morganas headed our direction - concentrate on the northernmost Morgana first.
We'll tackle the Morgana to our west second.
You must be joking.
Profintern? What did you say?
You heard me! Look at those ships! You have Cowardice up north, and Murder to the west.
Cowardice never goes anywhere quickly, while Murder will be steaming toward new targets in a matter of minutes. You honestly expect us to prioritize the more hapless target?

Fields.MenuText: That was the idea, Profintern.
You're out of line, Belle.
If you'd like to fight Murder yourself, you're more than welcome to swim out and greet her.

Fields.DialogueText: It was a bad idea.
Excuse me? I have a name, you know.
Your sincerity means the world to me.
It's true, Murder is a more conventional threat to the area than Cowardice. But Cowardice is all over the place - look at her.
So?
So she's unpredictable. If we leave her to her own devices, we can't be as confident about her next steps. And I think she can do more damage to the region in the long run.
The sooner we send Cowardice on her way, the sooner we can hunt Murder down and call this stretch of coastline secure.
Well, I think that's a bad call.
And I thank you for sharing. Now, can we get on with the fight?
*grumble*
@BATTLE
Profintern...
Da, Kapitan?
We're having a conversation now.
I hadn't realized.
No, I mean, we're having a conversation. Now.
If you say so.
You do realize I'm the captain of this ship, don't you? I mean, you did choose me as your captain.
It was very uncharacteristic of me. To this day, I can't quite explain how it happened.
But you do admit that you were the one who did the choosing, don't you? You don't have a twin or a doppleganger on board?
Nyet. I did choose you.
Then why do you feel the need to question my authority at every turn?
I don't question your authority at every turn.

Fields.MenuText: At three out of four turns?
Isn't that statement, in and of itself, questioning my authority?
Five minutes ago, I told a sailor his haircut looked sharp. What did you say immediately after?

Fields.DialogueText: Three out of four? That's... fair.
I'll question your authority if you say something blatantly incorrect.
That... only a blind man would say such a thing about such a haircut.
I know your intentions are good, Profintern - you want what's best for the ship and the crew. But there's a hierarchy aboard this ship for a reason.
If you're constantly undermining said hierarchy, the well-being of the ship itself is undermined.
... I suppose, on some level, I'm aware of that. I am.
Think you can attempt to rein in your revolutionary tendencies? For the good of the ship?
I'll... see what I can do.
@BATTLE
Don't look so sour.
I suppose... you may have a point.
You heard me! Get back to work! Everyone is expected to pull their weight on my ship!
Captain? I apologize if I'm interrupting...
No, no, Lieutenant Esposito, you're fine. What is it?
It's about Profintern.
Of course it is.
Are you aware of how she spends most nights?
Should I cringe ahead of time?
It's nothing so terrible. It's more just... strange.
How so?
She runs wind sprints.
Wind sprints?
All night.
You're serious?

Fields.MenuText: You're right, that is strange.
Does she ever sleep?
I'm exhausted just thinking about it.

Fields.DialogueText: That's why I thought it best that I bring it to your attention.
I've caught her napping every so often during the day. Other than that, no. I think she's awake most hours.
You and me both, Captain.
Thank you for letting me know, Esposito. Profintern hasn't been the easiest Belle to... figure out.
Well, I thought I might offer a little bit of advice.
At this point, I'll take whatever you can give me.
Keep in mind, the last thing I would ever want to do is compare a Belle to a domesticated animal...
But... ?
But... I have a dog at home, and if I leave him without anything to do for too long, he goes stir-crazy. Tears up the house, stays up all hours of the night...
You think Profintern might benefit from some purpose.
Yes, Captain. I'm of that mind.
*ALARM*
I appreciate your insight. Now, you'd better get to your station.
Yes, Captain.
@BATTLE
Profintern! Please, step inside my office for a moment.
... All right. What's wrong?
Why do you think something's wrong?
Because you don't typically speak to me unless something's wrong.
Ah. Well, nothing's wrong. Here, sit down.
This is all very odd, Kapitan.
I know, I know. My apologies. I was just hoping to ask you...
What interests do you have, Profintern?
Why do you ask?
You're the Belle of this ship. I'm just trying to get an idea of what makes you tick.
Hm. If you say so. Well... interests of mine... there's political theory, of course.
Of course.
Languages - I'm fluent in Russian, French and English, and speak a little Japanese, Chinese, German and Spanish.
Really?
I have a deep appreciation for Avant-Garde art. I paint from time to time. I wish we had a soccer ball aboard this boat, because I do love to play...
Slow down, slow down.

Fields.MenuText: You really know that many languages?
What sort of Avant-Garde art are we talking about here?
We do have a soccer ball on board. Two, in fact.

Fields.DialogueText: A lot is expected of us Soviet Belles. You should listen to Leningrad and I. We can have a conversation using words from six different languages in a single sentence.
Constructivism, specifically. Vladimir Tatlin was quite the visionary.
Tell me where they are. Now.
I had no idea that was an interest of yours, Profintern. Any others?
*mumble*
... What was that?
It's more... personal than that, Kaptain. I'm...
You're Jewish?
In the sense that you're actively practicing Judaism? I... wouldn't think Moscow would make that comfortable for you.
It doesn't have to be that active to become uncomfortable.
*ALARM*
Come on, let's go.
... All right.
@BATTLE
I think Lieutenant Esposito has them.
I'll be paying him a visit once we're done here...
... Jewish history and theology, Kapitan...
There's no reason to be ashamed of that. Every people's history is fascinating.
... Mostly, they deny it. "You're a ship, you're a servant of the state, you have no race, you have no religion." When I tried to argue, they started looking for "Jews who were leading me astray."
So I just keep it to myself. Unless I'm being questioned.

Fields.MenuText: ... Are you all right?
Everything about that is absolutely repulsive. I'm sorry.
... Right. We'll change the subject, then.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo.
Can we just change the subject?
I don't know how you expect me to answer that.
Lieutenant Esposito!
Yes, Captain?
Can you see if there's someone aboard the ship who can fix my typewriter? It's been giving me issues.
Certainly, Captain. How... how's it going with Profintern? If you don't mind my asking.
I checked with the ship's art and language aficionados. None of them were pleased at the prospect of Profintern joining their ranks.
You're the captain of the ship. You could just tell them that Profintern is joining, and that's that.
I could, but I'd have no guarantee that Profintern would show any interest in joining either.
And as we're both well aware, if Profintern doesn't want to do something, no urging on my part will convince her to do otherwise.
That does seem to be the case.
I assume she relieved you of the ship's two soccer balls.
She did. I tried to rally some of the other officers into playing a game with her...
What happened?
She ran circles around us. Literally. It didn't take long for the others to lose interest.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for trying, Esposito.
That girl has more energy than anyone I've ever seen.
I'm sure the gamblers on board found the match entertaining.

Fields.DialogueText: I do what I can, Captain.
I'd agree with that assessment, Captain.
The ones who'd bet on her sure did.
So, what are you going to do now?
I'm not sure. I still think your idea is a good one... I just need to find some means of implementing it.
*ALARM*
I wish you luck, Captain.
@BATTLE
Profintern? What are you doing in my office? Sitting at my desk?
I'm fixing your typewriter.
Pardon me?
Esposito was looking for someone to fix it. I said I would, and he seemed suspiciously enthused by my willingness.
Do you like fixing things?
Depends on the thing. But I do like working with mechanics, given the opportunity. Here, I've just put the finishing touches on your typewriter. Give it a look.

Fields.MenuText: ... It works better than it ever has. Profintern, this is impressive!
You know, I asked about your interests earlier. Why didn't you bring this one up?
Between mechanics, Constructivism, languages and soccer, you certainly have a wide array of interests, Profintern.

Fields.DialogueText: It's just a typewriter. It's not that impressive.
I wasn't aware you wanted an exhaustive list.
It's almost as if we Belles are living beings with depth and complexity.
Would you be open to helping the mechanics on board the ship? I know they're a little understaffed, at the moment.
*ALARM*
If they need the help, I don't see why not.
Excellent.
@BATTLE
I'll tell him to work on that.
Well, hello there, Cap! I don't see you down here very often. Come into my makeshift office, would you?
How are things, Sullivan? I heard you were in need of a few more mechanics.
We're making do for the time being.
We're supposed to have a new fellow join our ranks in a matter of days. He's well-known - a bit of a celebrity in the world of mechanics.
But we both know time means nothing to the Protection Fleet.
Well...
Yes...?
I have a suggestion. I'm not sure how you'll take it, but I would very much appreciate it if you would consider it.
If this is how you pitch all your ideas, Cap, your technique could use some work.
Ha, well. It's about the ship's Belle, Profintern.
I recently found out she has an interest in mechanics - and from what I've seen, she's not without skill - and I was wondering whether or not she could join your crew.
Is that so?
It wouldn't have to be a permanent thing. We could have a trial period, see how she does, how she meshes with everyone here.
... She's driving you insane, isn't she?
She really is.
Well, things have been pretty quiet down here, recently - we're not under a lot of pressure. So, I suppose I don't mind giving her a chance to show what she can do.
Really?
Captain, are you about... to cry?
... Must just be something in my eye.
*ALARM*
I have to go. Thank you, Sullivan. I'll send Profintern down here after the battle.
All right, all right. Good luck.
I've never served on a wackier ship in my life.
@BATTLE
Oh, glory. What'd she do now?
Well... It's nothing like that. I feel as if she needs some responsibility aboard this ship, beyond the services she already provides.
Profintern! You've... already introduced yourself to Sullivan, haven't you?
Well, you were taking too long to wrap things up after that last battle, so I decided to head down here myself. Is that a problem?
No, no. It doesn't surprise me in the least that you would take such initiative. How has your conversation gone?
I must say, you were correct, Cap. Profintern has quite the knowledge of mechanical systems. I would have put her to work weeks ago, had I known.

Fields.MenuText: I can't tell you how happy I am to hear that.
Well, I'm thrilled she will be an asset to your crew, Sullivan.
I owe Esposito big-time for this.

Fields.DialogueText: Why's that?
I haven't been given the job yet, Kapitan.
For what?
One last question, Profintern.
And what's that?
Should you take on work as a mechanic aboard this ship, I will be your supervisor. Will you be able to submit to my authority...
... an American's authority?
... Profintern?
I have no doubt that, when it comes to the realm of mechanics, you possess more knowledge than I. As such, I believe... I will be able to submit to your authority.
I'm happy to hear it. You can start work immediately.
*sigh*
Was that a sigh of relief I just heard, Kapitan?
@BATTLE
Oh! No real reason.
No?
No, Kapitan. Not yet.
Sorry. Private joke.
* ALARM *
Profintern? What happened to you? You're filthy.
Look at this part I just pulled! It was spraying oil everywhere.
You're... you're smiling. Ear to ear, even.
You don't need to sound quite so shocked.
Profintern has proven herself quite the asset to my team, Cap. I've never met someone so willing to get their hands dirty.
Mechanically speaking, of course.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'm proud of you, Profintern. Good work.
Try not to track oil everywhere. The crew just finished cleaning the deck.
You going to stick with this look for a while, Profintern? It's quite fetching.

Fields.DialogueText: Well... thanks, Kapitan.
I know, I know. I'm not about to make a mess of someone else's hard work.
You're hilarious, Kapitan.
Has she been like this the entire time?
Like what?
... Happy.
It took her a little while to get into the swing of things, but since she has, I've rarely seen her without a smile on her face.
You're kidding.
I am not. Some people thrive on work. Profintern must be one of them.
*ALARM*
Well, thanks for your help, Sullivan.
It's my pleasure, Cap.
@BATTLE
Listen up, crew! Contact with the enemy is imminent. As much as possible - hell of a caveat, I know - take their destroyers out of play first.
... Profintern?
Hmm?
You have something to say?
Why do you ask?
I expected you to pipe in. Say that we ought to focus on the heavier hitters first, or something.
Oh, the destroyers are a perfectly valid choice.
Really?
You want me to change my mind?
No, no, it's fine.
Do you think we maybe ought to... you know... engage?

Fields.MenuText: Ah, yes. Absolutely. Engage!
I'm getting there.
No, I thought I'd stand here and banter with you for a few more minutes.

Fields.DialogueText: There we go.
Sure you are.
Your funeral.
@BATTLE
What are you three eating?
Don't ask me. I tried pronouncing it once and Profintern shot me the death glare to end all death glares.
... Surnicky?
Syrniki.
Like I said. Profintern made them for us. Want one, Cap? They're little pastry... things.

Fields.MenuText: Sure! They look good.
Do they... taste okay?
Never took you for a culinarian, Profintern.

Fields.DialogueText: Help yourself.
I wouldn't have served them if I thought them inedible.
Why do you insist on using large words when a simple word like "cook" would do?
These are really good, Profintern. Thank you.
Well, I had a craving for proper Soviet food. The least I could do was share.
You know, Profintern...
Hmm?
I hope you don't mind my asking, but, what does your name mean?
Oh, I'm curious too. Enlight us uninformed Americans, would you?
Ah... um.
You're at a lost for words? Color me shocked.
Oh, hush. Profintern was the name commonly used to refer to the Red International of Labor Unions.
See, I told you it was a Communist thing.
You did.
The organization was formed to combat the International Federation of Trade Unions, and coordinated Communist activity within the unions.
Why are you talking about it in the past tense?
It... ceased to exist a few years ago. The Popular Front overtook it.
... And how do you feel about that, Profintern?
*ALARM*
Come on, we'd better take care of these Morganas.
... She's right. Let's go.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Privet, Kapitan.
*grunt*
Were you able to get any sleep at all?
Not really. But annoyance will see me through.
@BATTLE
Profintern? Profintern!
There you are, Kapitan! Come on, join the party.
Why the celebration? I mean, I know we won that last bout, but isn't this a bit much?
Oh, you should have seen her, Cap!
Seen who?
Profintern! We took some damage during that last battle, and the... well, actually, I'd rather not say, I wouldn't want you losing any more sleep over it.
W-what?
We were in a bad way for a few seconds, but then Profintern swooped in and fixed the problem, right then and there!

Fields.MenuText: Is that so? Well then... thanks, Profintern! Excellent work.
Ah, so that's where you disappeared to.
I would really rather you tell me what the problem was.

Fields.DialogueText: You're welcome, Kapitan.
Sorry for leaving without saying anything - but I knew time was of the essence.
Trust me, you don't want to know.
The crew put together this party for Profintern, in thanks for her service during that last battle. Wait here, Cap. I'll go get you a drink!
You look happy, Profintern.
Well... it's nice. Nice to be acknowledged. Appreciated.
I think most people would agree with you.
Profintern! Hey, what do you think about participating in today's strategy meeting? I think your insight could prove helpful.
Profintern?

Fields.MenuText: Profintern?
HEY! PRO! FIN! TERN!

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm? Oh, Kapitan. My apologies. What were you saying?
Aah! There's no need to yell, Kapitan!
... Oh! Kapitan. How long have you been standing there?
Something on your mind, Profintern?
Just... well... who is that?
Who?
That man, over there. Speaking with Sullivan.
Hmm? Oh, I think that's her new mechanic - some sort of hotshot from the States. Famous enough in the field for Moscow to consider his transfer something of a coup.
Oh. I see.
What's that look on your face all about?
Hmm? What look on my face?
*ALARM*
All right, the strategy meeting will have to wait. Meet up after the battle, all right?
Yes, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Sullivan's been waiting for him for a while now. One might even say she's been giddy about it... at least when tipsy.
*ALARM*
Everything okay, Profintern? Apart from the obvious?
It... should be, Kapitan.
That's not what I want to hear three minutes out from a shooting match.
Nyet, nyet! I'm sorry - just distracted. We're fine!
@BATTLE
Goodness! What a battle! Right, Esposito?
I'd have to agree with you there, Captain. I've never seen the ship perform as well as it did during that fight.
You have any idea why?
I think it's that new mechanic, Tate. At least, that's the word on the bridge. In the short time he's been here, he's already far exceeded everyone's expectations.
Is that him, over there? With the... rather large crowd surrounding him?
Heh, I think so. He's a charmer too. I think half the ship is already in love with him.
Oh, good grief. Well, I suppose I should finally introduce myself to the man.
Kapitan, I'd appreciate it if we could have a post-battle debrief. I have a few suggestions for alterations which should be made to the ship...
In a minute, Profintern - I need to check in with the new mechanic. Go to my office, and I'll meet you there in a bit.
What?
What's with that look on your face?
Oh, honestly.
Sullivan! Your team has really been outdoing themselves recently. Excellent work.
Save your praise for Tate, Cap. The rest of the team does their best, of course, but Tate is unlike anyone I've ever seen.
He's been up at all hours, tinkering, making everything run like new. Honestly, I've never met a mechanic as intuitive as he is. He keeps me on my toes.
Well, I'm glad we have him on our ship. Has Profintern spoken to you yet?
Profintern? About what?
She had some suggestions regarding alterations to be made to the ship. I told her to go ahead and speak to you about them.

Fields.MenuText: Well, there you are, Profintern!
Making your rounds?
Speak of the devil.

Fields.DialogueText: Had you thought me elsewhere?
As always.
Is that your opinion of me?
Sullivan, I... was wondering whether we could meet now. The alterations I'd like to suggest... well, I think the sooner we see to them, the better.
My apologies, Profintern - I told Tate I would meet him in a few minutes, to oversee some more of his work.
I promise, we'll meet as soon as possible, all right?
... All right.
Anything you need to say, Profintern?
*ALARM*
... Nyet. Let's go.
@BATTLE
Ah. She did tell me she wanted to meet with me. I'll make sure we do so soon.
It's an expression, Profintern.
Well, I'll be damned.
Oh, good grief.
*BOOM*
What was that?!
Not sure, Captain. I don't think it was a Morgana attack. Profintern?
Damn. Damn. Damn. Damn.
Profintern, where are you going?
I'll be back in-- as soon as possible. Just know, the ship might have some issues... moving.
Terrific.
@BATTLE
Profintern! Sullivan!
Here, Kapitan.
Yes, we're... here.

Fields.MenuText: I would very much appreciate it if someone would tell me what happened.
Details. Now.
Something exploded on my ship, before we were even in battle, didn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Captain.
I have a complete report for you, Captain.
I'm afraid so, Captain.
Engine trouble. The sort we couldn't see coming.
*Ahem*
Well... the sort most of us couldn't see coming.
Weren't the engines what Profintern wanted to speak to you about all this time?
They... were. And I am truly sorry, Cap - I've just been so busy overseeing the crew...
Ha.
Wha... what was that for?
The crew, I'm sure.
Profintern...
I take full responsibility for what happened, Captain. And rest assured, my team will not rest until the damage is repaired.
We'll see about that.
That doesn't bode well, does it?
No, it does not.
Esposito, tell me that isn't...
It's a strike.
... Of course it is. The mechanics?
Yes, Captain.
Led by Profintern?
You'd better believe it.
Unbelievable. Wait here, would you? Make sure I don't try anything stupid.
Nothing in any way stupid, or just not stupid enough to make her brain you with a pipe wrench?
Surprise me.
We are the backbone of this ship! We will not be downtrodden by the bourgeoisie!
All right, Profintern. I really don't think Sullivan can be considered the "bourgeoisie" in this instance.
Does she not employ us, the lowly mechanics, the proletariat? She sits in her office, lording over us all as we work, demeaning our efforts...
You have every right to be upset that Sullivan didn't take the time to listen to what you had to say about the engines. But saying she's demeaned her team's efforts? That's too far.
"Reserve the majority of your praise for Tate, Cap. The rest of the team does their best, of course, but Tate is unlike anyone I've ever seen." Did Sullivan not say that - to you?
Oh... boy.
And that's all we should ever have expected from an American - idolatry and selfishness! But I, I will lead these men and women.
*ALARM*
Let's go!
So, that went well.
You're such an encouragement to me, Esposito.
@BATTLE
We will not rest until we're given the respect and recognition we deserve!
The other mechanics seem a little less than thrilled over having set up camp on deck, Profintern. It's freezing out here.
It will toughen them up! A little cold never hurt anyone.
Esposito once lost two toes to frostbite.
Hey!
Sorry, just had to prove a point.
What do you want, Kapitan? I have no point of contention with you.
Aside from Sullivan and Tate, none of the mechanics aboard are working. That's going to catch up with us sooner rather than later.
I'm sure Sullivan is perfectly fine with that arrangement.
Profintern. I understand you're jealous of the attention Sullivan is showing Tate, but...
Jealous?!

Fields.MenuText: You are jealous... aren't you?
You heard me.
You know, I think I saw steam come out of your ears for a moment there.

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet. I am not.
Unfortunately, I did.
Shut up, you idiot.
Don't pretend to understand the inner workings of others, Kapitan. You're not good at it.
Then tell me, Profintern. What is this all about?
*ALARM*
Nyet.
Sorry for bringing up the toe thing.
There's the apology I was looking for.
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
You've got to be kidding me.
Captain, Morganas are closing the distance...
I know, I know.
If that was another one of the engines, we're in trouble. Profintern!
Profintern!
I'm on it, Captain. Don't worry.
Thanks, Sullivan.
@BATTLE
I can't believe we made it through that. Esposito!
Yes, Captain?
What's the ship's status? Was it an engine?
I'm afraid so. And Sullivan, well...

Fields.MenuText: Did something happen?
Out with it!
I don't like your tone...

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid so, Captain.
I'm getting there!
Well, you won't like what I have to say either.
Sullivan was able to make the necessary temporary repairs. But the blast caused the ship to take on water, and in this frigid climate...
Oh, no.
They're trying to warm her up in sick bay, and they're hopeful she'll recover. But when I saw her, well... she didn't look good.
Track down Profintern. Bring her to me.
Yes, Captain.
There she is, Captain.
Where are the other mechanics? They haven't left Profintern's side since the strike started.
Go ask her.
Profintern...?
Kapitan.
Where are the other mechanics?
Profintern.
They're with Sullivan in the sick bay.
So the strike, is it...?
It's over. Even before that last battle, the mechanics were losing interest. I could see it in their eyes. See the spark wane. In the end, they wouldn't even make eye contact with me.
You let me down, Profintern. I needed you during that last battle, and you didn't show.
I know. That was... that was wrong of me.
What's going on in your head, Profintern?
... I realize I'm a lot to take on, Kapitan. I realize I can get carried away.
Okay...
And I... I don't want to outlive my usefulness. So I'll step back.
What does that mean?
I'll be here for you during battles. But apart from that, you won't hear from me.
Profintern, that's not what I'm asking...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Esposito, how's Sullivan doing?
Word is she'll be back at work before we know it. She's a tough one.
Good, I'm glad to hear it.
Something on your mind, Esposito?
You heard from Profintern recently?
No. Only during battles.
You think we ought to... I don't know, look for her?
... I'm going to be honest with you, Esposito. Wrapping my mind around this Belle hasn't been the easiest task.
I know, Captain.
I mean, I try to find find ways of supporting her, but the smallest things seem to set her off, send her flying to one extreme or the other.
You sure they're small things?

Fields.MenuText: No? What makes you say that?
Do you know something I don't?
Are you about to drop some sage wisdom on me, Esposito?

Fields.DialogueText: Think about what we know of her, Captain.
No, you have all the knowledge I do.
We'll see about that.
So, what then?
Her namesake no longer exists. It was replaced by a new order.
Yes...
And the Jewish people are facing persecution left and right.
Right.
You think she might have some insecurities? You think those insecurities might be changing the way she behaves?
... Help me find her, would you? Who knows where she's holed up.
Of course, Captain.
@BATTLE
I'm sure they are. The question is how we can help her fix it.
*ALARM*
I've tried.
Some aren't. Some are.
But, yes, I'm well aware of the pressures she's under. The Soviet political officers have made it very clear to me that having her be invisible when not on duty is ideal from their perspective.
She's known all along that they wanted her silenced - about Judaism, about ship operations - and now I think she's so furious with herself over what happened to the Chief that she's just given up.
There's another dimension to this, too. It's not just her as an individual.
You'd think they'd have cut her some slack when she was railing against Sullivan, by the way - but, nope.
Half my job that week was shouting at people who wanted to lock her in a room until she confessed to thought crimes.
What... are you looking at, Captain?
Look up there. Does that look like...
Profintern sitting at the highest point atop the ship? Yes, it does.
Climbing up there ought to be fun.
You know what you're going to say to her once you do?
I'm working it out in my head as I go.
Really?

Fields.MenuText: Really. I like to think on my feet.
Actually, I've planned the entire thing out, word for word.
No. I'm hoping it will just come to me once I get up there.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, if you think you have everything under control, who am I to argue?
Heh. Well, I'm happy to hear you'll be going in prepared.
Just... don't make the situation worse than it already is.
*ALARM*
Great. She vanished.
I bet she'll retreat back up there after the battle.
I guess we'll have to wait and see.
@BATTLE
Your confidence in my abilities  inspires me, Esposito.
Profintern...
You didn't make it easy - getting up to you. I'll be lucky if I'm able to move my arms tomorrow.

Fields.MenuText: Not much for humor right now, then.
So, you still don't feel like talking.
Hell, I'll be lucky if I'm able to make it down from here.

Fields.DialogueText: Since you chose me as your captain, I realize things haven't gone smoothly. And that's not on any one person.
We're all scrambling, trying to make the best of this strange, new situation, and we're all bound to mess up.
... Esposito's been talking to you, hasn't he?
Well, he told me not to screw this up.
... You didn't.
Thanks. But, I'm serious - it's your job to tell me how I can support you. Because we can't win this war without you.
*ALARM*
Well... all right, then. I think I know how to start.
@BATTLE
I certainly did.

Fields.MenuText: I let your protest go because I didn't want to be one of the idiots telling you you had to be quiet.
I let your protest go because I was as exasperated with Sullivan and Tate as you were.
I'll spare you the full accounting of my sins unless you explicitly ask for it.

Fields.DialogueText: But I don't think I ever told you that I value your opinions. I don't think I ever told you that the ship runs better, in every possible way, when people listen to what you have to say.

Fields.MenuText: But it's the truth.
Even when you're being an incredible pain in the ass.

Fields.DialogueText: And I need you to get back to being open and active and occasionally frustrating. Immediately.
If you need something from me to make that happen, then tell me. Because, obviously, I have a mixed record at guessing.
Sullivan?
Well, hello there, Cap. Haven't seen you in a while.
How are you feeling?
Honestly, I think those docs in the sick bay were just making a big deal over nothing. Hypothermia couldn't keep me down.
Happy to be back at work?
You'd better believe it.
Good. I'm glad to hear it.
This... just a social visit, Cap?
Not exactly.
Yeah... I didn't think so.
For the sake of my mental health, will the two of you please talk things out while I'm still relatively young? Sullivan?
I... am sorry, Profintern. I wasn't fair to you or the rest of the mechanics. I allowed my admiration of Tate to get in the way of my job, and that was immensely unprofessional of me.
And I guess I probably shouldn't have... you know... led a strike against you.
Heh.
*ALARM*
Think you two can get back to working together?
It make take some time, but...
Probably.
Good.
@BATTLE
... Hello.
So, Profintern wants to clear the air, and she's asked me to mediate. Who'd like to talk first?
Good. Keep going.
The ship is my body, and... and it felt like it just didn't matter how I felt or what I knew, and....
Okay, you can stop. Point made.
Well, you nearly froze to death to save me, so I guess I can forgive you.
And thank you for that, by the way. Spasibo. You've... you've been a good friend when it counted, and.....
... Don't make me hug you, you little gremlin.
And, yeah, I really am sorry.
*ALARM*
Vot oni idut!
We're ready for them.
@BATTLE
You did... reasonably well during that battle, Kapitan.
Well, that's kind of you to say, Profintern. Where are you off to?
Well, Esposito said he'd try to arrange another soccer game.... Provided I promise to give the others a chance. I was going to go meet up with them.
You... want to come?
You're inviting me to play with you?
I can be thoughtful!
I know, I know! I was just surprised.
I have some paperwork to finish up.
Oh...
But it shouldn't take long. I'll meet up with you all as soon as I do.
Well... good!
Anything else you want to say, Profintern?
... Just that, well... I've decided you're a decent kapitan, Kapitan.
And what would I do without your good opinion, Profintern?
Be a shell of a human being?

Fields.MenuText: Heh. Right.
... Believe it or not, I do value your good opinion, Profintern. Greatly.

Fields.DialogueText: And don't you forget it.
Sure you do.
See you at the pitch. Unless you're afraid to lose.
Try me and see.
Nyet. Quite well.
